comments.commentBody:
A joke told in prison where, because the same jokes have been told and retold countless times before, inmates save time by simply assigning numbers to well-known jokes, then shouting out a joke's number instead of the entire joke and its punchline. But because this joke is being told in a facility for the criminally insane, the inmates have assigned it an irrational number: "Pi."

(Guffaws abound.)
A joke about Dean Martin's stint at Sea World: "That's a moray!"
A joke about why vampires in the TWILIGHT series have such impressive slugging percentages:  "They're baseball bats!"
A joke about the worst name opposing tee-ball players can use to taunt a first-year  player:  "Baby batter!"

A joke about Sir Galahad attending a royal singing contest:
"A Knight at the Opera"

A joke about Buckingham Palace after receiving a new paint job:
"Castle Blanca"

Punch line to a joke about Sir Ronald A. Fisher (1890-1962), considered by many to be the "Father" of both Statistics and Mathematical Genetics and who coined about 25 terms in Stat, including "consistency", "efficiency", and "sufficiency" (all first used in Stat in a paper of his in 1922): Who could ask for anything more?

A joke about a woman at the beach who's afraid to go in the water:
"Lady in wading."
Let me relay a European joke. If you know several languages, you are multilingual; if you know two languages, you are bilingual; if you only know one language, you are: AMERICAN.
A joke about an ambivalent alcoholic.  The punch line is, "Neither beer nor there."
Punch line to a joke about quarks: They're up and down, top to bottom, strange with charm.
A joke about an apprehended angry pedestrian. "Caught in a Crosswalk."
The punchline for a toothless vampire reduced to picking through trash: " Once in a while I find one and I make some tea!"
A joke about jokes, and the punchline is: "I'm serious."

What does Jose want to do?  Let's see what he feel comfortable with, he is one of the franchise players ( or has that status changed?) And thanks, David ( post #1) for saying it; Olie should not be in the rotation.  Send him....somewhere... I don't care, it pains me to see the box score when he pitches.

besides richard conn and GM ron henley (karpov's associate for many years), there is also an advisory board where americans are heavily represented.
http://www.karpov2010.org/advisory-board/

whether the american representation indicates strength or weakness in karpov's candidacy is unclear. at the UN or the IMF, the US has the loudest voice. in FIDE politics the US has not been particularly influential. the USCF flirts with bankruptcy from time to time and has struggled with internecine lawsuits by former board members until recently. of course there is also bobby fischer, an amazing chess player, who was not exactly known for sound judgment away from the chess board.
New York has been down a prima donna ever since the departure of Kathleen Battle.  This Clevelander wishes LeBron would just go and fill that gap. Buh-bye!

The recent anti-immigrant sentiment in Arizona is nothing new. Going back 30-35 years ago, Arizona was a hotbed for "English-only" laws and opposition to bilingual education in the schools. When my mother was growing up in Arizona as a child in the 1940's and 1950's, students were prohibited from speaking Spanish at school, and were subject to after-school detention if they were caught speaking Spanish.

The Republican party in Arizona has also had a history of trying to discourage minorities from voting under the guise of "ballot security". Former Supreme Court Justice William Rehnquist was involved in some of these activities.

There does not seem to be a distinction between the activities of most illegal immigrants, who are largely law abiding (aside from their immigration status) and are filling jobs that others do not want such as agricultural pickers, janitors, etc., versus those of the drug trafficers and people smugglers. In many ways, the bias against allowing channels for legal immigration and the draconian laws such as those in Arizona only serve to strengthen the position of the people smugglers and drug trafficers (by way of analogy, prohibition enhanced the economic power of moonshiners).

Tucson is a great place. Come on down there is plenty to do, Desert, Mountains, Music, and a great climate with fun people.  Don't deprive yourself just because a lot of num-nuts have nothing better to do.  Got extra money? Buy a winter house here, we had a mortgage bubble and there are lots of 60% off homes.  All of this political theater will vanish anyway as soon as the next big thing comes along..
Dream on, jacobi, and then get used to Speaker Pelosi.  You're going to hear that for some time to come.

I failed to read anything in the article that said these were "Wall Street" bankers. However, even if some of them were, i think they realize they can't BUY the support of the democrats through their contributions - at least not like they can buy legislation through the Republicans.

If anyone here doesn't remember what Bush said when the democrats took over in January 2007, let me refresh your memory. He said: ""If the Democrats want to test us, that's why they give the president the veto. I'm looking forward to vetoing excessive spending, and I'm looking forward to having the United States Congress support my veto."
June 2007: "Bush plans to veto the Homeland Security appropriations bill nearing final passage, followed by vetoes of eight more money bills sent him by the Democratic-controlled Congress. That constitutes a veto onslaught of historic proportions from a president who did not reject a single bill during his first term. Of the 12 appropriations bills for fiscal year 2008, only three will be signed by the president in the form shaped by the House. What's more, Bush correctly claimed he has the one-third plus one House votes needed to sustain these vetoes. The unpopular president is taking the offensive on fiscal responsibility. After bowing to Republican demands on earmarks, Democratic leadership face a battle of the budget."

So, the president had the veto pen and used it and the democrats had to use the "pay as you go".

@ #12 Patricia Monger

You bring up an important point. The concern has less to do with the wording of the law than how the police enforce the law.

Viewed that way people seem to be saying they don't trust the police. People are essentially saying the police will exploit this law to harass innocent citizens. Like the police are just waiting to be given the green light to Go Get Some Mexicans. People are afraid the police will abuse the law so they're saying the law is wrong.

Maybe sometimes that's not far from the truth. I'm afraid of the police myself.

But... fear is not valid decision making criteria. Arizona's law is not racist but the chance of a racist implimentaion of the law exists. These chances always exist.

It is a battle for the hearts and minds of the American people. The federal government, now headed by Mr. Obama, versus the people of Arizona. The threats of boycotts, legal rhetoric, and slanderous misinformation of what the Arizona law states, will fall by the wayside. It will not deter the law-enforcement agencies in Arizona to do what they are required to do.

Enforce the law.

The federal government along with John McCain have done a disservice to the people of Arizona...they have put their personal political careers ahead of the problems facing our country. It is but one of the reasons why the anti-incumbent movement is now in full swing.

Americans must now pull with the state of Arizona, resist the radical extremes that are trying to demoralize and confuse the issues of right and wrong. President Obama in a bold statement condemned the new Arizona law on illegal immigration, setting of the radicals through out the country, implying that the Arizona enforcement officers could not be fair and honest in doing their job.

It is a battle for the hearts and minds of all Americans.

After living in AZ for nearly 25 years, I can say this is all so rich, and the backlash richly deserved. The AZ 'cons learned nothing from the boycotts protesting the cancelled MLK-day, a short-lived stunt pulled during the heyday of Governor Of The Foil Hat Brigade, Ev Mecham. Perhaps surprising to many, current-Governor Jan Brewer was a member of either the AZ house or senate then; I've forgotten which.

What's particularly rich to me isn't the fire-breathing right; nor the many, many genuine AZ racists; nor the pandering, abject cowardice of the governor and assorted state "leaders." The richness, the irony, comes from the idea of business people who do everything including exploiting and destroying good peoples' lives in pursuit of the better bottom line, righteously protesting against the AZ business people who implicitly encourage immigration, then exploit and destroy immigrants' lives, in pursuit of the better bottom line.

For the second time in my life, I fully support the AZ boycotts; I wish only that the motives weren't so blatantly hypocritical.
The vast majority of people in this country might prefer ignoring the First Amendment.  We expect a higher standard from responsible leaders.
